list.title: Question 2
list.content: Find the equations of the two tangents to the curve $y=2x2−x+29​$ that pass through the origin.
list.markScheme:
To better understand the scenario we can make an approximate sketch.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/35659e47-9a77-41ce-ac75-a15e57624b06/images/c4b81b1f-14ca-47a5-8ee8-d6eb7e19b7ea/AA1285.JPEG)


The dashed lines are the two tangent lines whose equations we need to find.
The equation of a tangent line, through the origin, will be of the form
$$$y​=mx​(M1)​$$$
To find the intersection points of the curve and line we can solve both equations simultaneously, hence
$$$mx00​=2x2−x+29​=2x2−x−mx+29​=2x2−(1+m)x+29​​(M1)(A1)​$$$
If the lines are tangent to the curve then there is only one point of intersection i.e. only $1$ solution.
As we have a quadratic equation then we can say that the discriminant must be equal to zero. Hence
$$$Δ0​=b2−4ac=[−(1+m)]2−4(2)(29​)​A1​$$$
Solving for $m$ we get
$$$36−(1+m)m​=[−(1+m)]2=±6=−7 and 5​$$$
Therefore the two equations are
$$$​y=−7x​ and y=5x​​A1​$$$

list.content:
Show that $12logx​2=log2​x12​$. [1]



Hence solve the equation $log2​x=8−12logx​2$.[4]
list.markScheme:
Using the change of base formula we can write
$$$L.H.S.​=12logx​2=12(log2​xlog2​2​)​A1​$$$
As $logn​n=1$, we can replace $log2​2$ with 1 and simplify
$$$​=12(log2​x1​)=log2​x12​​ ...as required=R.H.S.​$$$


We can replace $12logx​2$ with the R.H.S. of the identity from part (a)
$$$log2​xlog2​x​=8−12logx​2=8−log2​x12​​(M1)​$$$
We now multiply each side by $log2​x$ and then rearrange such that the R.H.S. is equal to $0$
$$$(log2​x)2(log2​x)2−8log2​x+12​=8log2​x−12=0​(M1)​$$$
This is a hidden quadratic equation.  If we replace $log2​$ with a variable, say $a$, we get
$$$a2−8a+12​=0​$$$
Let's solve this by factorising.
$$$(a−2)(a−6)​=0​$$$
Therefore the solutions are
$$$a−2a​=0=2​and​​a−6=0a=6​$$$
Recall $a=log2​x$, therefore the solutions become
$$$log2​x​=2​​​log2​x=6​A1​$$$
Converting each to exponential form, we get
$$$x​=22x=4​​​​x=26x=64​​A1​$$$

$an​(−1)na0​​$

$$$αβ​=2k(−1)2(3k+6)​αβ=2k3k+6​​​$$$

$$$x​=4k−15k±(15k)2−4(2k)(3k+6)​​=4−15​±4k201k2−48k​​​$$$
This implies that there must be at least one negative root, and it is therefore not possible to have two positive roots.
If the product of the roots is positive, then the polynomial will have two negative roots.

$$$b2−4ac201k2−48kk(201k−48)k​>0>0>0<0 , k>20148​​$$$
